tit.e: The Preface of A Collection of Ancient and Modern Japanese Poetry
The Preface to "A Collection of Ancient and Modern Japanese Poetry"
The Preface to "A Collection of Ancient and Modern Japanese Poetry"

sen.j: 古今和歌集仮名序（こきんわかしゅうかなじょ）は古今和歌集の序文である。
sen.e: Kokin Waka shu Kanajo is a preface of A Collection of Ancient and Modern Japanes Poetry.
Kokin Wakashu Kanajo is a preface to "A Collection of Ancient and Modern Japanese Poetry."
sen.cmt: made "Waka shu" into "Wakashu" for consistency with other articles I have seen; fixed typo, added quotation marks
sen.e: Kokin Wakashu Kanajo (The Preface to "A Collection of Ancient and Modern Japanese Poetry") is a preface to Kokin Wakashu (A Collection of Ancient and Modern Japanese Poetry).
sen.cmt: 古今和歌集 を追加しました。

sen.j: 仮名 (文字)で書かれていることから「仮名序」と呼ばれている。
sen.e: It's called Kanajo because it was written in Kana (the Japanese syllabary).
Its title, "Kanajo," is based on the fact that it was written in Kana (the Japanese syllabary).
sen.cmt: fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: Its title, 'Kanajo,' is based on the fact that it was written in Kana (the Japanese syllabary).

sen.j: 執筆者は紀貫之であり、初めて本格的に和歌を論じた歌論である。
sen.e: The author of the preface was KI no Tsurayuki, and it was the first full-scale treatise on Waka (thirty-one-syllable poems).
The author of the preface was KI no Tsurayuki, and it was the first full-scale treatise on waka (thirty-one-syllable poems).
sen.cmt: fixed spacing; made "waka" lowercase for consistency with other articles
sen.e: The author of the preface was KI no Tsurayuki, and it was the first full-scale treatise on waka (thirty-one-syllable poems).

sen.j: また歌学のさきがけとしても知られる。
sen.e: It is also known as a pioneering study of poetry.
It is also known as a pioneering study of poetry.
It is also known as a pioneering study of poetry.

sen.j: 仮名序は、冒頭で和歌の本質とは何かを解き明かした後、和歌の成り立ちについて述べ、次いで、和歌を6分類し各分類について説明する。
sen.e: The preface explained what waka's nature is in the opening, followed by the history of waka, and then it divided waka into six groups, each of which was explained further.
The preface explains the nature of waka, followed by the history of waka, and then divided into six waka groups, each of which is explained further.
sen.cmt: fixed grammar to read more naturally; changed to present tense
sen.e: The preface explains the nature of waka in the opening sentence, followed by the history of waka, and then divided into six waka groups, each of which is explained further.

sen.j: そして、和歌のあるべき姿を論じ、その理想像として2人の歌聖（柿本人麻呂と山部赤人）を挙げ、次に近代の高名な6人の歌人（六歌仙）を挙げる。
sen.e: The preface illustrated how desirable waka should be, and mentioned two names of Great Poets-KAKINOMOTO no Hitomaro and YAMABE no Akahito, and in addition to that, it listed modern famous six poets (Six Immortal Poets).

The preface illustrates how desirable waka should be, mentioning the two names of Great Poets, KAKINOMOTO no Hitomaro and YAMABE no Akahito in addition to listing six famous modern poets (lit. Six Immortal Poets).
sen.cmt: fixed grammar to read more naturally; added "lit" since the explanation seemed to reiterate what was already translated
sen.e: The preface illustrates how desirable waka should be, mentioning the two names of Great Poets, KAKINOMOTO no Hitomaro and YAMABE no Akahito in addition to listing six famous modern poets (lit. Six Immortal Poets).

sen.j: 最後に古今集の撰集過程について触れた後、和歌の将来像を述べて終わる。
sen.e: In the last part, the preface referred to the process of compiling the anthology, and ended with future prospects of waka.
In the final section, the preface refers to the process of compiling the anthology and ends with the future prospects of waka.
In the final section, the preface refers to the process of compiling the anthology and ends with the future prospects of waka.

sen.j: やまとうたは、人のこころをたねとして、万の言の葉とぞなれりける。
sen.e: Seeds in people's minds grow into tens of thousands of words, and that is what the Japanese poetry is.
The seeds in peoples' minds grow into tens of thousands of words, and that is the essence of Japanese poetry.
sen.cmt: fixed grammar and word selection to read more naturally
sen.e: The seeds in peoples' minds grow into tens of thousands of words, and that is the essence of Japanese poetry.

sen.j: 世の中にある人、事・業しげきものなれば、心に思ふ事を、見るもの聞くものにつけて、言ひいだせるなり。
sen.e: People in the world are likely to express what they have in mind everytime they see and hear things as they experience many things under various situations.
People in the world are likely to express what they have in mind every time they see and hear things as well as when they experience many things under various situations.
sen.cmt: fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: People in the world are likely to express what they have in mind every time they see and hear things as well as when they experience many things under various situations.

sen.j: 花に鳴く鶯、水に住むかはづの声を聞けば、生きとし生きるもの、いづれか歌をよまざりける。
sen.e: How could they refrain from making poems when they listen to warblers in the blossoms or frogs in the water?
How could they refrain from making poems when they listen to nightingales in the blossoms or frogs in the water?
sen.cmt: if 鶯 can be translated to either "warbler" or "nightingale" I think "nightingale" is the more well-known choice
sen.e: How could they refrain from making poems when they listen to nightingales in the blossoms or frogs in the water?

sen.j: 力をも入れずして天地を動かし、目に見えぬ鬼神をもあはれと思はせ、男女のなかをもやはらげ、猛き武士の心をもなぐさむるは、歌なり。
sen.e: It is poetry that, without any strength, shakes the heaven and the earth, makes invisible spirits moved, makes a man and woman intimate and eases a worrior's violent soul.
